coredata.dc:title: A comparison of the multipole-expansion and point-charge models of the electrostatic energy between polar diatomic molecules
coredata.dc:creator: Thomas Brobjer, J.
Murrell, John N.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A comparison is made of the multipole-expansion and point-charge models of the electrostatic energy for the dimers (HF)2 and (LiH)2. For the same degree of computational effort the point-charge models are better, and a two-site model with otf-atom sites performs consistently well.

Introduction Empirical potentials which represent the interac- tion between polar molecules contain as an important term a representation of the electrostatic energy It lias been common practice for small molecules to write tins energy as a multipole expansion, the leading term for neutral polar molecules being the dipole—dipole energy However, the rate of convergence of this ex- pansion depends on the distance between the mole- cules. For van der Waals contact, intermolecular distances may be of the same order as intramolecular distances and the convergence may be slow. For large molecules, or whenever intermolecular distances are smaller tlian intramolecular distances, the electrostatic energy is more commonly obtained by summing over the point-charge interactions arising from a finite number of discrete charges situated on each molecule This approach is less commonly used for small molecules but m this brief communication we are suggesting that even for these it is generally more efficient than the multipole expansion The question at issue is how many terms are required to give an accurate representation of the energy using the multipole and the site models It can be assumed that with enough multipole terms or enough sites, an accurate electrostatic energy can be obtained provided the electron densities of the two molecules do not overlap significantly But which model requires the 'fewer terms9 To emphasize the current relevance of this question we note that in a recent computer simulation of liquid HC1, the addition of dipole and quadrupole terms to a neutral site—site potential was found to change appre- ciably the pair distribution function [1 ] 2. Results We base our analysis on the multipole moments and multipole interaction energies for HF and LiH calcu- lated by Ng et al [2] Their objective was to examine the effect of electron penetration on the multipole terms. Model (a) has only one parameter for neutral molecules and the magnitude of the site charge can be determin- ed to reproduce the dipole moment.
